name: Universiteit Maastricht
goal:
Maastricht University (UM), founded in 1976, is a Dutch public university and one of the best young universities in the world. It is the most international university in the Netherlands and has a distinct European profile in research and education. UM has been awarded prestigious quality certificates from the Accreditation Organisation of the Netherlands and Flanders (NVAO): the Institutional Quality Assurance Assessment and the Distinctive Quality Feature for Internationalisation (CeQuInt).

UM stands out for its innovative education model, international character, multidisciplinary approach to research and education and strong focus on social engagement and impact. UM’s approximately 17.000 students (53 % of whom are non-Dutch) represent over a 100 nationalities and a large proportion of its approximately 4000 staff members are international.

UM, through its CORE (Collaborative Open Research Education) Strategic Programme 2017-2021, has set the following goals:

1. To be an innovator in education and research
2. To adopt an inclusive approach and to open its doors to all students and staff who fit its profile and subscribe to its values
3. To link the university to society, from the local to the global level
4. To be a sustainable institution in the broadest sense

In pursuing these goals, UM works together with a variety of local, regional and international partners in education, government and industry. This includes, participating in three leading European and international university networks/alliances: the Young European Research Universities Network (YERUN), the Worldwide Universities Network (WUN) and the Young Universities for the Future of Europe (YUFE) alliance, and leading and/or contributing to important cross-border activities, such as:

• The Brightlands Campuses, a triple helix collaboration between UM, the Province of Limburg and several companies
• The Aastricht-Maachen Institute for Biobased Materials
• The Institute for Transnational and Euregional cross border cooperation and mobility
• The European Graduate School of Neuroscience
• Regenerative Medicine Crossing Borders (RegMed XB)

UM’s research is organised around and focused on three themes: Quality of Life, Learning and Innovation and Europe and a Globalising World. Issues that fall under these themes are healthy ageing, climate change, demographic changes, sustainability, societal impact of digital and technological developments, healthy and affordable food, and the European integration process.

euInitiatives: UM actively follows EU policies and initiatives in the field of education and research. These include the EU Framework Programmes for Research and Innovation, namely: Horizon 2020 and Horizon Europe, The European Innovation Council pilot; policies for the European Education Area (including, but not limited to staff and student mobility under Erasmus+); European Strategy Forum on Research Infrastructures (ESFRI);  Open Innovation,  Open Science and Open to the World.
